answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Brian,
I have been able to find quite a few documents that should be help to answer your question. To begin, there were two programs nominated for the Community Sustainability Award that created initiatives to enforce codes and reduce the number of vacant lots in their jurisdictions. Sandy Springs, Georgia created the Vacant Property Enforcement Program that resulted in the development of a systematic inspection program to enforce codes and deter future crime. 
http://bit.ly/dQDkDW
Another award nominee was the city of Manassas, Virginia’s Week of Hope. This program not only encouraged residents to comply with zoning regulations for their own properties, but also to encourage the community clean its other vacant lots. In 2008 this program was able to save the city $142,244 in man-hours.
http://bit.ly/gZ1dt4
In terms of cost, there was a case study done in 2009 about the cost of vacancies in Baltimore. Throughout the document there are tables that depict the varying costs associated with the problems vacant properties can bring.
http://bit.ly/gu66Kn
There has also been a case study regarding management strategies to combat vacant properties in two hypothetical neighborhoods from the perspective to three local government leaders.
http://bit.ly/fKJlJ0
The League of California Cities published an article in 2009 that describes how municipalities can combat the challenges presented by foreclosed homes and the different ordinances developed to address the problem in California.
http://bit.ly/gqXYZr
Finally, Flint, Michigan created a Neighborhood Stabilization Plan in 2008 specifically targeted towards getting government funding to aid in redeveloping abandoned or foreclosed properties.
http://bit.ly/dQ76Yx
I hope this helps!
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org

author: Brian Knudsen
text:
Are there examples of other organizations that have made a policy decision to either maintain landscaping in forclosed properties or to leave it as is?
Is there any analysis on the cost benefit of maintaining landscaping or letting it "get out of control" and then it becoming a health hazard - to be removed by code enforcement?
Thanks for your help.
title: City maintaining Lanscaping on forclosed properties
